PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  During  the  country  programming  mission  held  in  Manila  in  December  2012,  the 
Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) requested the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) to assist the Enshi Tujia and Miao Autonomous Prefecture (ETMAP) of Hubei Province to 
prepare the Hubei Enshi Qing River Upstream Environment Rehabilitation Project which is 
included in the lending program for 2015 under the PRC: Country Operations Business Plan 
2013–2015. A project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) will help ensure compliance with 
ADB’s requirements and incorporation of international best practices in the project design.  
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
 
2.  The  PPTA  implementation  will  be  in  two  parts.  Part  1  will  include  a  preliminary 
examination of the existing and potential public private partnership arrangements with regard to 
the two wastewater treatment plants to be expanded and to determine the coordination between 
ADB and the existing plants, and the scope of advisory services related to public private 
partnership. Part 2 will address the required due diligence: (i) assess the technical feasibility of 
the project; (ii) conduct due diligence on the economic and financial feasibility of the project; (iii) 
review  safeguards  requirements;  (iv)  conduct  social  survey  and  consultations;  (v)  conduct 
procurement assessment and identify training needs; (vi) develop the capacity of the ETMAP for 
project  management;  and  (vii)  prepare  project  documents,  including  the  draft  report  and 
recommendation  of the  President (RRP)  and key  linked  documents. The key  outputs  and 
activities are summarized in Table A4.1.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
 
3.  The PPTA is estimated to cost $800,000 equivalent, of which $600,000 will be financed 
on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources), and 
$200,000 will be financed on a grant basis by the Multi-Donor Trust Fund1 under the Water 
Financing Partnership Facility, and administered by ADB. The cofinancier funds will be utilized 
on a front loading basis. The ETMAP will provide in-kind contributions including counterpart staff 
remuneration  and  transport,  logistic  support  in  arranging  workshops  and  field  visits,  fully 
functional office space for consultants with water and utility supply, a telephone line and access 
to internet, and other in-kind contributions. The government has been informed that approval of 
the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. The detailed cost estimates are 
presented in Table A4.2.

D.  Consulting Services 
 
4.  One individual international consultant for 1.0 person-month (pm) will be recruited to 
conduct PPTA activities under Part 1. The construction and operation of the expansion of 
Lichuan Wastewater Treatment Plant will need to be negotiated with the current private operator 
before further due diligence can be conducted for that subcomponent. Part 2 will be carried out 
by a team of consultants through a firm. A total of 15.0 pm of international and 34.0 pm of 
national consulting services will be required. The consulting firm will be selected by (i) inviting 
simplified technical proposals and (ii) using the quality- and cost-based selection method, with a 
quality–cost ratio of 80:20. The terms of reference for the PPTA consultants are described in the 
Attachment. Table A4.3 provides details of the required expertise.

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
5.  The ETMAP will be the executing agency. The implementing agencies include the Enshi 
Urban Development and Investment Co., Ltd., Lichuan Wastewater Treatment Plant, Hongmiao 
Wastewater  Treatment  Plant  (for  Enshi  City),  Enshi  City  Government,  and  Lichuan  City 
Government. A project leading group has been established in the ETMAP to provide overall 
guidance and to ensure coordination across sectors for PPTA implementation. The leading 
group is headed by the Governor of ETMAP, and senior officials from the departments of 
development  and  reform  commission,  finance,  housing  and  urban  rural  development 
commission, environment protection, water resources and fishery, land resources and forestry. 
A  project  management  office  has  also  been  established  to  administer  day-to-day  PPTA 
activities and coordinate with ADB and the implementing  agencies. The two project cities, 
including Enshi and Lichuan, will also establish local project implementation offices to carry out 
project  activities  under  their  jurisdiction.  Disbursements  under  the  PPTA  will  be  done  in 
accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (May 2010, as amended 
from time to time).  
 
6.  The PPTA will be implemented over 16 months tentatively from 1 September 2013 to 31 
December 2014 (including three months for financial closing). The proposed PPTA’s processing 
and implementation schedule is listed in Table 4.4.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR THE CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Consulting Service Requirements 
 
1.  The project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) will provide for the Government of 
the People’s Republic of China (PRC) 16 person-months (pm) of international and 34 pm of 
national  consulting  services  to  help  the  government  prepare  the  Hubei  Enshi  Qing  River 
Upstream  Environment  Rehabilitation  Project  for  possible  lending  support  by  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB). The PPTA will be implemented in two parts. 
 
B.  Consulting services for Part 1 
 
2.  Public private partnership specialist (international, 1.0 pm).  The specialist will have a 
degree in engineering, economics, law, finance or a related field and at least 7 years of work 
experience in formulating and/or implementing public private partnership projects in the water 
supply and sanitation sector. The specialist will (i) review the concession agreement between 
the Lichuan City Environmental Protection Bureau (LCEPB) and the Wuhan Zheng Yuan Water 
Management Company (WZYWMC) on the existing facilities of Lichuan Waste Water Treatment 
Plant and the proposed concession agreement governing the expansion; (ii) review the current 
allocation of risks and rewards under the existing and proposed concession agreements and, as 
necessary, propose changes that could achieve a fair and reasonable allocation among the 
parties, (iii) propose a structuring and financing options for the expansion of the wastewater 
treatment plant to ensure technically efficient operations and commercial and financial viability; 
(iv)  prepare  recommendations  to  LCEPB  on  concession  negotiations;  (v)  assess  the 
management and technical capacity of the Enshi Liyuan Urban Wastewater Management Co. 
proposed for the management  of the  Enshi  Hongmiao Wastewater Treatment  Plant  to  be 
expanded;  and  (vi)  make  recommendations  for  improving  management  capacity  of  the 
wastewater treatment plants to be financed by the ADB loan. 
 
C.  Consulting services for Part 2 
 
3.  Environment  and  water  resources  management  specialist/team  leader 
(international,  6.0  pm).  The  specialist  will  have  an  advanced  degree  in  hydrology,  civil 
engineering,  environmental  management,  urban  planning,  or  other  related  fields  and  work 
experience in formulating projects. The specialist will have overall responsibility for effective and 
timely implementation of the PPTA and quality of all PPTA outputs, and coordinating and 
consolidating inputs of government agencies and other specialists. Specifically, the specialist 
will (i) coordinate all TA activities as team leader, including stakeholder participation; (ii) manage 
consultant team members and lead in formulating project design and feasibility study, including 
conducting  peer  review  of  the  domestic  feasibility  study  reports;  (iii)  prepare  a  sector 
assessment report, based on a review of the master plans (at the prefectural, provincial, and 
national levels) for water resource management and pollution control in Qing river basin, and 
relevant laws and regulations; (iv) develop the project design and monitoring framework; (v) 
establish a project performance monitoring system; (vi) prepare the project implementation 
schedule and detailed implementation arrangements; (vii) prepare inception, interim, draft final, 
and final reports, including a draft report and recommendation of the president (RRP) and 
related linked documents in ADB format; and (viii) organize workshops and implement training 
to develop the capacity of the executing and implementing agencies. 
 
4.  Environment specialists (international, 2.5 pm; national, 5.0 pm). The specialists will 
have  (i)  an  advanced  degree  (for  international)  or  bachelor’s  degree  (for  national)  in

environment  and  water  resource  management  or  relevant  field;  (ii)  at  least  15  years 
(international)  and  10  years  (national)  of  experience  in  environmental  impact  assessment, 
including a track record in water infrastructure and water resources projects. The specialists will 
undertake the following tasks: (i) document the existing conditions and baseline status of key 
environmental parameters in the project area; (ii) assess potential project impacts, particularly 
from  dredging,  embankment,  disposal  of  treated  sludge,  and  cumulative  impacts  when 
considered with other planned developments in the upper Qing river system; (iii) develop project 
mitigation measures and assess any residual (net) impacts; (iv) based on existing data, or a 
simplified climate model (such as Climate 1 stop), assess likely changes in temperature and 
precipitation amounts, and likelihood of severe storms; and (v) contribute to overall project 
design, to maximize project environmental benefits and minimize adverse impacts.  
 
5.  Environmental institution and policy specialist (international, 1.5 pm). The specialist 
will have an advanced degree in environment and water resource management or relevant field, 
and at least 7 years of work experience in pollution management. The specialist will propose 
project activities for improving capacity of water resource management dealing with issues not 
addressed by the engineering components of the project, including: (i) reviewing provincial 
policies for water pollution and assessing the capacity of the environment protection bureaus for 
water/soil  monitoring,  and  identifying  project  opportunities  for  strengthening  local  policy, 
monitoring, and enforcement; (ii) in coordination with the rural development specialist, selecting 
sites for participatory programs to reduce nonpoint source pollution and to prevent littering along 
the river banks; (iii) designing institutional strengthening measures to improve environmental 
monitoring and enforcement; and (iv) assessing the feasibility and institutional arrangements for 
an integrated water resource management information system. 
 
6.  Rural  development  specialist  (international,  2.0  pm).  The  specialist  will  have  an 
advanced degree in rural development, agricultural extension, or a related field, and at least 10 
years of experience in designing and implementing participatory agricultural extension programs 
or other community based rural development programs.  The specialist will have extensive 
experience working with Participatory Rural Appraisal and other rural and/or social development 
tools  and  qualitative  and  quantitative  analysis  methodologies.  Working  with  other  team 
members, design institutes, executing agency, and ADB, the specialist will (i) lead the detailed 
design of project Component 3(i) design of a participatory community program to reduce non-
point source pollution, to be implemented in the five-year construction phase of the project, and 
(ii) in coordination with the social development specialist, incorporate inclusive features in the 
community based program to ensure that vulnerable groups (including women and indigenous 
peoples) will benefit from the project. The specialist will provide guidance and ensure capturing 
into project design and RRP, reports, project administration manual, and design and monitoring 
framework, of work provided by the relevant national specialists such as social development, 
nonpoint source pollution, and resettlement. 
 
7.  Economic and financial specialist (international, 3.0 pm). The specialist will have an 
advanced degree in economics or finance, and at least 7 years of work experience in economic 
and financial analyses of ADB- or World Bank-financed projects. The specialist will undertake 
the following tasks: (i) review project cost estimates, financing plan, and financial projections; (ii) 
conduct project economic and financial analyses, covering demand analysis, least economic 
cost analysis, economic and financial cost-and-benefit analysis, economic and financial internal 
rates of return, sensitivity analysis, and benefit distributional analysis; (iii) design and conduct 
survey  and  collect  secondary  data  to  assess  willingness-to-pay  for  wastewater  treatment, 
affordability  analysis,  and  other  issues  related  to  economic  analysis;  (iv)  identify  financing 
mechanisms for project cost recovery, considering tariff reforms for wastewater treatment and

collection; (vi) review the fund flow, loan repayment, and disbursement arrangements; and (vii) 
provide inputs to the sector assessment report. 
 
8.  Flood management specialist/deputy team leader (national, 6.0 pm). The specialist 
will have a bachelor’s degree in hydraulic engineering and over 10 years of experience in 
designing hydraulic engineering projects in a variety of countries. The specialist will undertake 
the following tasks: (i) review the master plans (at the municipal, prefectural, provincial, and 
national levels) for flood control in Qing river basin; (ii) assess flooding risk in the upstream area 
of Qing river basin, including the need for detailed hydrological modeling to properly identify 
zones of highest flood risk requiring interventions; (iii) conduct peer review of detailed designs of 
embankment, platforms, access roads, and other associated facilities; (iv) identify the project’s 
key technical risks, particularly impact on river hydraulics characteristics in nearby areas outside 
of the project engineering sites; (v)  provide inputs to the economic model for sensitivity and risk 
analyses;  (vi)  identify  ‘associated  facilities’  to  the  project,  and  if  necessary,  conduct  due 
diligence on potential structural issues of relevance as per ADB Safeguards Policy Statement 
(2009);  (vii)  given  projected  temperature  and  precipitation  changes,  conduct  a  sensitivity 
analysis  to  ensure  that  flood  management  component  design  can  accommodate  potential 
variability; and (viii) review the technical capacity and experience of executing agency and 
implementing agency staff to design, supervise, and manage the implementation of project 
facilities. 
 
9.  Wastewater  management  specialist (national,  5.0  pm). The  specialist  will  have  a 
bachelor’s degree in sewage or related fields and at least 10 years of work experience in 
designing wastewater treatment facilities and collection systems. The specialist will undertake 
the following tasks: (i) review the land use and wastewater master plans for Enshi and Lichuan 
cities to ensure consistency of proposed project activities regarding wastewater treatment and 
collection with existing planning; (ii) conduct peer review of the design for the wastewater 
treatment and collection subcomponents proposed by the Enshi Tujia and Miao Autonomous 
Prefecture, including verifying design standards, hydraulic calculations, cost estimates, and 
drawings for instruction and installation works; (iii) provide recommendations for improving the 
original design; (iv) review the technical capacity and experience of executing agency and 
implementing agency staff to design, supervise, and manage the implementation of project 
facilities;  (v)  given  projected  temperature  and  precipitation  changes,  conduct  a  sensitivity 
analysis to ensure that system design can accommodate potential variability due to climate 
change; and (vi) provide necessary inputs to the draft RRP.  
 
10.  Climate change specialist (national, 1.0 pm). The specialist will have (i) a graduate 
degree in hydrology, water engineering, ecology or environment, or equivalent; (ii) at least 10 
years of experience in water engineering and climate change; and (iii) demonstrated expertise 
in evaluating potential impacts of climate change and making recommendations for adaptation 
in the water sector. The specialist will: (i) collect and analyze information related to climate 
change  impacts  (environmental,  economic,  and  social  impacts)  and  projections  (predicted 
changes in temperature and precipitation) in the project area; (ii) use simple climate models 
such as “Climate 1-Stop" (http://arcserver4.iagt.org/climate1stop/) to make projections, if data 
are  not  available;  and  (iii)  help  identify  opportunities  for  climate  proofing,  adaptation,  and 
mitigation actions and/or activities in the water sector. 
 
11.  Riparian and wetlands ecosystems specialist (national, 2.0 pm). The specialist will 
have an advanced degree in wetlands management and at least 10 years of experience in 
wetlands  management  and  research.  The  specialist  will  undertake  the  following  tasks:  (i) 
document the wetland functional and biodiversity values of the project sites and river sections

immediately  downstream  (i.e.  the  river  sections  which  might  be  impacted  by  the  project), 
including the presence of threatened and/or protected flora and fauna and role of the project 
river sections in overall river function for the upper Qing river system; (ii) prepare a map 
showing  locations  and/or  zones  of  biodiversity  value  and  ecological  river  function  in  and 
immediately downstream of the project sites; (iii) assess potential project impacts to wetland 
biodiversity  and  river  function;  (iv)  assess  potential  climate  change  impacts  on  riverine 
environment and biodiversity; and (v) identify the specific ecological variables to be included in 
the environmental monitoring program being prepared by the team environment specialists. 
 
12.  Social development and resettlement specialists (national, 4.0 pm [resettlement] and 
2.0  pm  [social  development]).  The  specialists  will  have  an  advanced  degree  in  social 
safeguards  and/or  development  studies  and  work  experience  in  resettlement  and/or  social 
development studies. The specialists will undertake the following tasks: (i) collect data on land 
acquisition  and  resettlement  impacts;  (ii)  assist  the  Enshi  Tujia  and  Miao  Autonomous 
Prefecture in preparing a resettlement plan for each city; (iii) conduct a poverty and social 
analysis, including gender issues; (iv) prepare a consultation and participation plan and a social 
action plan; (v) conduct a labor analysis; (vi) assess impacts on ethnic minorities and prepare 
an ethnic minority development plan for each city; and (vii) provide necessary inputs to the draft 
RRP.  
 
13.  Agricultural nonpoint pollution control specialist (national, 3.0 pm). The specialist 
will have a degree in agricultural extension, environmental management or a related field, and 
at least 5 years of experience in agricultural extension and environmental management. In 
coordination with the international social development specialist, the specialist will undertake the 
following tasks: (i) select at least two river sections (one in each city) for two pilot community 
participatory  programs  on  nonpoint  source  pollution  to  be  implemented  during  loan 
implementation; (ii) design a pilot community participatory program for farmers to promote more 
environmentally  proper  application  of  fertilizers  and  pesticides,  including  the  use  of  an 
information  and  communication  technology-based  agricultural  technical  support  network 
developed under a previous ADB TA;2 (iii) prepare the proposed approach, methods, timing, 
and budget for the two pilot programs, in participation with the selected communities; (iv) 
develop baseline data for key pollutants in the pilot sites; (v) prepare a cost estimate and any 
printed materials needed for the pilot participatory program; (vi) provide inputs to the draft RRP; 
and (vii) summarize the findings as inputs to the final report. 
 
14.  Economist (national, 2.0 pm). The specialist will have a bachelor’s degree in economics 
or finance, and at least 7 years of work experience in project economic analysis of ADB- or 
World Bank-financed projects. The specialist will undertake the following tasks: (i) assist the 
international economist in accomplishing the tasks related to economic analysis of the proposed 
project; (ii) in coordination with the international economic and financial specialist, conduct 
demand analysis, least cost analysis, distribution analysis, sensitivity and risk analysis, estimate 
main types of benefits using primary and secondary data, and calculate economic internal rate 
of  return  for  all  subcomponents  and  the  overall  project;  and  (iii)  in  coordination  with  the 
international  economic  and  financial  specialist,  design  and  implement  willingness-to-pay 
analysis for wastewater treatment and collection.

15.  Financial specialist (national, 2.0 pm). The specialist will have a bachelor’s degree in 
economics or finance, and at least 7 years of work experience in project financial analysis of 
ADB- or World Bank-financed projects. The specialist will undertake the following tasks: (i) 
assist the international economist in accomplishing the tasks related to the financial analysis of 
the proposed project; and (ii) in coordination with the international economic and financial 
specialist, (a) prepare cost estimates financial plan, and financial sustainability analysis, (b) 
evaluate the historical financial performance of all entities that manage the revenue-generating 
subcomponents; (c) calculate the financial internal rate of return for all revenue-generating 
subcomponents  and  associated  sensitivity  and  risk  analysis;  (d)  review  existing  levels, 
structures  and  policies  for  wastewater  tariffs  and  propose  reforms  to  ensure  financial 
sustainability of wastewater treatment and collection facilities.  
 
16.  Financial  management  specialist  (national,  1.0  pm).  The  specialist  will  have  a 
bachelor’s  degree  in  financial  management  or  related  field,  a  recognized  professional 
accounting qualification and at least 5 years of work experience in project financial management 
assessment.  The  specialist  will  undertake  the  following  tasks:  (i)  conduct  a  financial 
management assessment of the executing and implementing agencies; (ii) assess their policies 
and capacity for financial and disbursement management, and identify any further need for 
capacity building; (iii) review existing procedures for disbursement, funds flow, and approvals, 
and recommend streamlined funds flow and procedures for contracting and disbursement under 
the project, and internal control and audits; (iv) review on-lending arrangements; and (v) assist 
in financial projections and financial analysis. 
 
17.  Project management and procurement specialist (national, 1.0 pm). The specialist 
will have a bachelor’s degree in engineering and at least 7 years of work experience in project 
management, and in procurement and consulting services. The specialist will undertake the 
following  tasks:  (i)  conduct  procurement  capacity  assessment  for  all  the  executing  and 
implementing agencies to undertake procurement and consultant recruitments required under 
the project; (ii) prepare a procurement plan, including: (a) contract packages indicating the 
procurement  method  for  each  contract  and  the  source  of  financing;  and  (b)  indicative 
procurement schedule and implementation schedule indicating the tasks on the critical path; (iii) 
prepare sample bidding document; (iv) assess the capacity of the executing and implementing 
agencies for project implementation, and propose training events in procurement and consulting 
services procedures under ADB financed operations; (iv) provide necessary trainings on project 
management, procurement, and consulting services; and (v) assist in developing the design and 
monitoring framework and performance targets.
